name: Simply Chess
description: The classic board game comes to Steam with asynchronous online play and 100 levels of AI. If you are a chess enthusiast or someone who just likes to play a game now and again, this is what you've been looking for. This is Simply Chess.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP or better Processor: 1 gHz Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: OpenGL 2.1+ w/ GL_ARB_framebuffer_object Storage: 300 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP or better Processor: 2 gHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: OpenGL 3+ Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 300 MB available space

I looked at the other chess games and they seemed dated and flawed , so I tried this and am very pleased so far. The UI is intuitive. It shows all moves that can be made. The main reason I like it though is that it has 100 levels that start out pretty easy. I've tried other games that had a few levels and I just got murdered every game. I would make some mistake and that would be it. Here I can slowly work up and improve, and it's a lot more enjoyable. Haven't tried the online or anything, but the computer AI at least starts out at a level where I can improve without getting wiped out little by little.

This is a game with chess that is free, with integrated multiplayer.  It has ads, yes. But they can be removed for a reasonable price.  The dev team have been quick to fix bugs, and have kept in constant contact with the community. The game is plain, and could do with some improving. But it is clear that they listen, and for any issues, just approach the devs through the discussions.  On a side note, anyone complaining that this game is free, and saying that is a bad thing? You are absolute morons. It is free, and to try to use that as a negative purely on the basis of it's being free is inherently anti-consumer. You can literally test out if this game is for you, without paying a penny up front. Buy premium if you want to feel like you've bought this game. otherwise, just enjoy that it's free.  Of everything on steam, a decent, free chess game with a responsive developer is a breath of fresh air, compared to all the pay-for Slaughtering Grounds and Temper Tantrums that just want your money and don't care about quality.  Of course, this isn't the best chess game out there. but with the dev team pushing through the bugs, and their quick response time to critique, I've no doubt in my mind that this game will get better.

This game is what you would expect from a Chess game; it's good old Chess on Steam, and it's free.  You can play against a computer, your friends, or online. If you choose to play against the computer; you get the option to adjust its difficulty setting from 1 to 100, the higher the number, the smarter the A.I. I haven't played against the computer yet; because I prefer to play against other people, (despite the fact that I'm not very good at Chess.)  It is very easy to find someone online, the longest I have ever had to wait to play against someone online would probably only be about one minute.   Although I prefer to get out a real board and play off that; I would still recommend anyone who is interested to at least try it (especially since it doesn't cost any money.)

As far as I can tell this is the only Chess game on steam that's free. Though it's still being updated, it has steam support. a descent AI system, online battles with a tad bit of delay but that's fine and the ability to set the board to 2D mode or 3D with a rotatable camera.  Some critisicisms though: -The board orientation never changes depending on which side you choose, white will always be on the bottom. (Fixed) -There is a bit of jitteriness with 3D but that might be the fault of my crap PC -The GUI for games doesn't seem very appealing but it's ok (Fixed) -Even though everything is recognisable, the art style is just lacking that simplistic and crispy look that I've come to enjoy in Chess games. -Barely any different styles. -Ads that you have to pay to get rid of -no drag and drop (Fixed) -no timer so people can go AFK if they know they've lost and thus forcing you to concede from impatience  At the end of the day, it's free chess, it's fine (though a bit lackluster)   oh yeah, and controller support...for some reason

Simply bad. It does not even work on 64bit Ubuntu where it installs wrong libraries and then reports error messages about missing libraries.   Internet chess have evolved during the years, so why don't the devs check a client like Jin or Win/Xboard, and the features servers like FICS and ICS, and start from there. The matchmaking system presented in Simply Chess is horribly clunky compared to Seeks in FICS and ICS.   Moreover, nobody ever needs or use 3D boards, it's just a gimmick, instead, the devs should concentrate on useful features, like useable seeks, chat channels, adjournment and adjudicate systems, proper time controls with increments (quite important on the internet), etc.

A good time waster. I am by no means a chess genius so AI level 6 seems to be about my skill level. I notice the AI has a few quirks at this level. It doesn't seem to grasp the concept that the king can defend itself in a limited fashion. It thinks it has me beat by putting it's queen next to my king. King takes queen.  It's also very protective of it's pieces. For example if there's ever a situation where it could take my rook by sacrificing a bishop it will never take my rook, even if it would put it in a better position strategically speaking. This basically allows me to control the board by purposefully putting my pieces in dangerous sitations forcing it to back off. It probably doesn't act this way at higher levels.  Other than that, it's chess and it's free. There's probably a million others out there just like it but this is the first that's made it to Steam.
